channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: How to Host a Company Holiday Party During Covid?
item.description: But ordinary times these are not.   One benefit of an online holiday party?   You’ll find everything you need right here. What is Slack’s video function but an opportunity for embarrassment waiting to happen? We aren’t so sure. “At corporate holiday parties, you typically get a handful of folks who end up drinking too much and do something embarrassing,” Ryan Costello of Event Farm told the WSJ.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Jobless Claims, Food Insecurity Rise
item.description: Housing: A homebuying boom has added a collective $1 trillion in homeowner equity this year (an average of $17,000 per homeowner), according to CoreLogic. Applications from self-employed and gig workers for a federal program rose 48%, but that program expires Dec. 26.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Disney Announces Disney+ Content Slate
item.description: Zoom out: Disney’s streaming unit is growing rapidly, but still incurring big losses ($2.8 billion in fiscal year 2020) that analysts expect to peak in the next two years.   But Disney isn't planning to follow WarnerMedia down that path just yet. WarnerMedia is planning joint theater-HBO Max premieres next year.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: FDA Approves Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine, Raising Questions Over Who Counts as Essential
item.description: Now comes the hard part  Pfizer, BioNTech, and other manufacturers have generated lifesaving products at a breathtaking speed...   Bottom line: It will ultimately fall to the states to decide which workers are “essential” enough to receive the first, limited doses of the vaccine. Currently, the only clear directive is that healthcare workers and residents of long-term care facilities go first—and no industry reps dispute that.   Unblinding would hamstring the research process... but it would also get people vaccinated.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: FDA Approves Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine, Raising Questions Over Who Counts as Essential
item.description: Now comes the hard part  Pfizer, BioNTech, and other manufacturers have generated lifesaving products at a breathtaking speed...   Bottom line: It will ultimately fall to the states to decide which workers are “essential” enough to receive the first, limited doses of the vaccine.   Some states have drafted plans for distribution, but many of them don’t match up.   Unblinding would hamstring the research process... Currently, the only clear directive is that healthcare workers and residents of long-term care facilities go first—and no industry reps dispute that.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: December 11
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: ETFs: Everything You Need To Know, And Then Some
item.description: One More ETF FYI As a beginner investment vehicle, ETFs can be a wonderful way to get a hang of the market and all of its fluctuations. If your brokerage charges you fees when you buy or sell ETF shares, its cost effectiveness can go out the window.   ETFs can track indexes from bonds to the NASDAQ, so find one that represents your own risk-tolerance and long-term plan.   An under-the-radar stock that could overperform. You can find out what the management team tracks their performance to, which is a good indicator to determine if you want that for your own portfolio. So good luck, and ETFs FTW. ETFs are not Always Cheaper It’s true, ETFs can be more cost-effective for the average investor than other funds.   In case you forgot, ETFs—or Exchange-Traded Funds—are funds that are traded on public exchanges just like a stock. If you read our Ultimate Guide to Investing, created with our friends at The Motley Fool, you’ll remember our comparison of ETFs to succulents.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Google's Top Trending Searches in 2020
item.description: 1) Cut men’s hair at home 2) plop hair 3) color your hair at home Lyrics: 1) WAP 🧐 Definitions: 1) WAP 🧐🧐🧐 1) My stimulus money 2) my refunds 3) Kansas City How to...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: ‘Cyberpunk 2077’ Debuts to Enormous Hype and Positive Reviews
item.description: The WSJ forecasts Cyberpunk 2077 will sell between 18 million and 25 million copies in its first month since a) it’s such a hyped game and b) it’s the only major title coming out during the holiday season. For real.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: International News Updates
item.description: Canada: The country’s health regulator approved Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid-19 vaccine, becoming the second nation after the UK to do so.   Brazil: Passengers on a Gol Airlines flight from Sao Paulo to Porto Alegre were the first in nearly two years to travel on a Boeing 737 Max, which returned to commercial service yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Faces Two Antitrust Lawsuits at the Federal and State Levels
item.description: Bottom line: These lawsuits probably aren't the Jake Paul to Facebook’s Nate Robinson...   Yesterday, the twin investigations emerged from their chrysalises into full-fledged lawsuits.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Airbnb Goes Public After Turbulent Year for Travel
item.description: The company had a roller-coaster year. If this week’s IPOs were a music festival, DoorDash would be the opener that rocked so hard everyone started moshing. As a public company, Airbnb will face a number of challenges, including angry city officials, concerns over safety, and a rising number of professional hosts who threaten Airbnb’s identity as a platform that connects people with... To swing the pendulum back toward individuals, Airbnb is creating a host endowment fund through its IPO to invest in the people who make its platform work.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Airbnb Goes Public After Turbulent Year for Travel
item.description: The company had a roller-coaster year. If this week’s IPOs were a music festival, DoorDash would be the opener that rocked so hard everyone started moshing. As a public company, Airbnb will face a number of challenges, including angry city officials, concerns over safety, and a rising number of professional hosts who threaten Airbnb’s identity as a platform that connects people with...   Just because you survived the travel industry’s worst downturn ever doesn’t mean you can nap.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Faces Two Antitrust Lawsuits at the Federal and State Levels
item.description: Bottom line: Facebook stock barely budged on the announcement, so these lawsuits probably aren't the Jake Paul to Facebook’s Nate Robinson.   Yesterday, the twin investigations emerged from their chrysalises into full-fledged lawsuits.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: International News Updates
item.description: Canada: The country’s health regulator approved Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid-19 vaccine, becoming the second nation after the UK to do so. It’s a tense issue considering more than 40% of India’s workforce is employed in agriculture. The laws loosened some rules around the pricing and storage of crops, and farmers argue the deregulation will devastate their incomes.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple Unveils the AirPods Max, Its First Over-Ear Headphones
item.description: If you're looking for a new way to flex on your Zoom calls, Apple unveiled its first over-ear headphones yesterday, the AirPods Max. It'd be quite the flex. the headphones arrive Dec. 15, and Apple's workout service, Fitness+ ($9.99/mo.   Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: HBO Max: Strong User Growth, But Fallout From Upending Theatrical Window Continues
item.description: According to AT&T CEO John Stankey, HBO Max will notch 12.6 million activated accounts by today.   The straight-to-streaming decision has upset Hollywood creators. 30... In a fiery statement Monday night, filmmaker Christopher Nolan said, "They don't even understand what they're losing.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Cybersecurity Giant FireEye Suffers Massive Attack
item.description: So this is like if an animal control office got infested by raccoons.   What FireEye is: the go-to security provider for governments and companies that suffer sophisticated hacks; for instance, it helped Sony and Equifax bulletproof their operations following breaches.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: The UK Begins Its Inoculation Program in Busy Day for Vaccines
item.description: It's hard not to get a little emotional when looking at this picture of 90-year-old grandmother Margaret Keenan receiving a standing O from hospital staff in England yesterday morning.   You might think the UK rolling out its mass inoculation program was enough vaccine news for one day, but there were several other important developments.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: DoorDash IPO Could Value It at $36B
item.description: Today, DoorDash says it has 58% of the suburban market.   The pandemic solidified DoorDash's lead in the U.S. food delivery industry, catapulting its market share to nearly 50% (No. 2 Uber Eats has 28%). Q2 revenue jumped 214% annually, propelling DoorDash to the first profitable quarter for a food delivery company. DoorDash reportedly priced its shares at $102 a pop, which, on a fully diluted basis, would equate to about a $39 billion market cap.     Why the hype? As food delivery companies went wheel-to-wheel in cities, DoorDash opted for a market with less competition: the 'burbs.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Apple Unveils the AirPods Max, Its First Over-Ear Headphones
item.description: If you're looking for a new way to flex on your Zoom calls, Apple unveiled its first over-ear headphones yesterday, the AirPods Max. It'd be quite the flex. the headphones arrive Dec. 15, and Apple's workout service, Fitness+ ($9.99/mo.   Looking ahead...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: DoorDash IPO Could Value Startup at $36B
item.description: Today, DoorDash says it has 58% of the suburban market.   The pandemic solidified DoorDash's lead in the U.S. food delivery industry, catapulting its market share to nearly 50% (No. 2 Uber Eats has 28%). Q2 revenue jumped 214% annually, propelling DoorDash to the first profitable quarter for a food delivery company. And with DoorDash commissions climbing as high as 30%, restaurants may look for cheaper options.     Why the hype? Raising $3+ billion should help. Monthly subscribers have more than tripled to 5 million, and 390,000+ merchants use its app. Is the balance sheet keeping up?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Morning Brew Grammar Blog, No. 6: Rules Are Rules, Except When They’re Not
item.description: People sometimes think a run-on sentence is one that has...     Gets the job done, but now it’s not entirely clear which piece of information the reader should be focused on.    Long sentences can be run-ons, but it’s not their length that makes them so.   Unhelpful Rule No. 1: Run-on sentences = writer jail Run-ons are definitely to be avoided, but it’s important to remember the actual definition of a run-on.   Way better.   News Cycle Case Study  In this section, I focus on a recent news story and explain why it’s tricky for people to write about.   Active voice: JPMorgan underwrote the listing.   That’s all I have for this edition.   Passive voice: The listing was underwritten by JPMorgan.   In this case, the passive voice is fine because the actors who elected Reagan (i.e., U.S. voters) aren’t important to the sentence; the year is the focus. But in some instances, we don’t need to avoid the passive voice like it’s an indoor gathering—because it’s not actually important who’s doing the acting.   Unhelpful Rule No. 2: Passive voice = writer jail  What’s the passive voice?   Bottom line: Correct sentences are correct sentences; length is irrelevant. Grammar “rules” are really more like guidelines that come with asterisks and exceptions and unlesses. This is a series about grammar and style.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Ikea to Stop Making Iconic Catalog After this Year
item.description: Bottom line: Online furniture sales have been a pandemic winner for retailers like Wayfair and Amazon, so Ikea's decision to focus on its digital operations makes business sense.   + While we're here: If you're feeling nostalgic, visit the digital Ikea museum to leaf through decades of past catalog issues.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: China Trade Surplus Reaches Highest Level Ever
item.description: S-China trade deficit is closely watched because one of President Trump's main economic goals was to reduce the imbalance by slapping tariffs on Chinese goods. In November, China posted its biggest month for exports on record, and its trade surplus—the amount by which exports exceed imports—topped $75 billion.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Bob Dylan Sells Songwriting Catalog to the Universal Music Publishing Group in Historic Deal
item.description: Yesterday, cultural icon/harmonica player Bob Dylan sold his entire catalog of more than 600+ songs to the Universal Music Publishing Group. Why it matters: Dylan is one of the most famous artists of all time, and his catalog is considered a priceless treasure of the music canon.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Uber Sells Self-Driving Division to Aurora Innovations
item.description: Why Uber is letting go:  Self-driving cars are expensive. Uber is reportedly unloading its air taxi division too.   Big picture: Several self-driving startups have downsized or closed shop during the pandemic.   Who is Aurora? Subscribe to Emerging Tech Brew. Experts predict more consolidation ahead. The pandemic walloped ride hailing.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: California Water Futures are First to Trade on Chicago Mercantile Exchange
item.description: If you buy a futures contract, you agree to purchase the asset at a predetermined price on a future date.   California farmers could use the help California is the country's largest water market by a magnitude of four, but its water supply is less consistent than a container of strawberries in January. Investors can buy futures contracts for everything from fresh bacon to Burgundy wine, but the commoditization of an element critical to daily life is worrying to some observers—especially as water access becomes more strained." California's spot water market is worth ~$1.1 billion.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Q3 2020 Recap
item.description: Professional golf has been underway for months with only minor testing headaches, while the pandemic-era versions of the Tour de France, the U.S. Open in tennis, and the Kentucky Derby went off smoothly. If the first two quarters of the year meant us coming to terms with a global pandemic, Q3 saw us settling into a ~new normal~ of face masks, parking lot dining, and saying "whoops, sorry!"   So what about K-12?   Q3 was the busiest for public offerings since the dot-com era.   That was a lot.   The election, for one.   Over the last three months, extreme weather events made more intense and frequent by human-induced climate change have ravaged communities across the country. There's actually good news.   Pulse check on the economic recovery  It's...   So why are biz leaders wearing out DocuSign?   Looking ahead On the monetary side...   On the corporate side...   On the fiscal side...   Looking ahead... School Reopenings Test Students, College Towns, and Parents After schools across the country closed their doors in the spring, John Krasinski hosted virtual prom, graduation ceremonies were streamed online, and at least one student accidentally said, “Sup, b****?”   Soccer: A  This summer, the National Women's Soccer League became the first major U.S. sports league to return to action from the Covid break, while the MLS has already welcomed fans back in certain states.    How the Economic Recovery Fared in Q3 As the ink dries on Q3, nearly 900,000 Americans are filing new jobless claims each week.   The Atlantic Coast produced so many big tropical storms that the World Meteorological Organization depleted its list of 21 names by September and is now using the Greek alphabet. Even where students can attend school, many parents have chosen not to enroll them. University of Iowa students angered Twitter (an easy feat, really) by lining up for downtown bars in Iowa City, which earlier this month had the fourth-highest Covid-19 cases per capita in the U.S. But for local businesses like The Airliner bar, students returning to campus is their only lifeline—revenue was $0 in April.   Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images Parts of the West Coast have been ablaze since August, with a record 3.7 million acres burned across California. Climate change is no longer one of those problems. the M&A could keep flowing, but experts think the IPO frenzy will settle by late October.   Whether you want to relive summer 2020 or would rather pretend it never happened, we present: the Brew's third quarter recap. Basketball: A+  Zero NBA players have tested positive for Covid-19 since entering the famous "bubble" in Orlando. The Tampa Bay Rays, the Brew’s July pick to win it all, entered the postseason as the top team in the American League. But with the election and a Supreme Court fight ahead, don't hold your breath for more emergency aid until the Christmas lights come out.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Uber Sells Self-Driving Division to Aurora Innovations
item.description: Uber is reportedly unloading its air taxi division too.   Why Uber is letting go:  Self-driving cars are expensive.   Who is Aurora? Uber hasn’t completely given up on AVs—it’ll eventually use Aurora's self-driving cars.   Big picture: Several self-driving startups have downsized or closed shop during the pandemic. Subscribe to Emerging Tech Brew.
item.author: Alex Hickey
